TextEquiv.Unicode: ding. Adulterie is judged to be a sinne
worthy of death and endlesse infamie.
For the Lord in the lawe doth not say
onely, Thou shalt not commit adulte
rie, But in another place also goeth
on, and addeth: And he that commit
teth adulterie with another mannes
wife, even he that committeth adul
tery with his neighbours wife, let both
the adulterer and the adulteresse bee
slaine. Levit. 20. And this punish
ment of adultery by death was not ab
rogated or chaunged by the very Gen
tiles. For the Romane law called Lex
Julia is very wel knowen, how it com
manded adulterers to be put to death.
Which law was of force in the time of
S. Hierome, as we may gather by the
hystory which he wrate of an adulte
resse, at the chopping off of whole head
seven strokes were give. Neither is it
marvaile undoubtedly, that adultery
was among them of old, and is yet at
this day according to the lawes, to bee
punished by death. For upon that one
many sinnes do depend.
First of all the adulterer is a perju
red man. For he hath broken and vio
lated the faith which he gave opely be
fore God and the face of the Cogrega
tion by calling to witnesse the most
holy and reverend Trinity, when the
minister of Christ did solemnize the
marriage and couple him to his wife,
by giving hand in hande. Secondari
ly the adulterer hath committed theft
and robberie. For whe the adulteresse
doth make her body common to an o
ther man, then doth she set to sale, de
file and marre, not her owne, but her
husbandes bodye. Thirdly bastardes
borne in adulterie do often times en
joy an equall parte of inheritaunce
with the right begotte childre. Which
cannot be without great wrong done
to the lawfull heyres and legitimate

ding. Adulterie is judged to be a sinne worthy of death and endlesse infamie. For the Lord in the lawe doth not say onely, Thou shalt not commit adulte rie, But in another place also goeth on, and addeth: And he that commit teth adulterie with another mannes wife, even he that committeth adul tery with his neighbours wife, let both the adulterer and the adulteresse bee slaine. Levit. 20. And this punish ment of adultery by death was not ab rogated or chaunged by the very Gen tiles. For the Romane law called Lex Julia is very wel knowen, how it com manded adulterers to be put to death. Which law was of force in the time of S. Hierome, as we may gather by the hystory which he wrate of an adulte resse, at the chopping off of whole head seven strokes were give. Neither is it marvaile undoubtedly, that adultery was among them of old, and is yet at this day according to the lawes, to bee punished by death. For upon that one many sinnes do depend. First of all the adulterer is a perju red man. For he hath broken and vio lated the faith which he gave opely be fore God and the face of the Cogrega tion by calling to witnesse the most holy and reverend Trinity, when the minister of Christ did solemnize the marriage and couple him to his wife, by giving hand in hande. Secondari ly the adulterer hath committed theft and robberie. For whe the adulteresse doth make her body common to an o ther man, then doth she set to sale, de file and marre, not her owne, but her husbandes bodye. Thirdly bastardes borne in adulterie do often times en joy an equall parte of inheritaunce with the right begotte childre. Which cannot be without great wrong done to the lawfull heyres and legitimate
ofspring. For they are against al right
robbed of their due inheritance, wher
of an equall position is given to him, to
whom by lawe no parcell is due. Last
ly beside all these, innumerable mis
chiefers doe spring of adulterie. Since
therefore that it is a Serpent with so
many heads, both the lawes of God &
me doe rightly punish adulterers with
losse of life.
But some jolly fellowes there are
forsooth, that of adultery do make but
a sport. They are perswaded that Da
vids adultery doth make on their side,
and that place of scripture, where wee
read, that the Lord was savourable to
the adulteresse, that was taken eve as
the deede was in doing. Why doe not
these merrye conceyted men consider
howe severely the Lorde did punishe
David for that offence? The bloudye
house of David was immediatly after
defiled with filthie incest. For Amnon
doth perforce defloure his sister Tha
mar. And streight way upon the necke
of that again, his house is defamed by
most cruell parricide, while Absolom
in a banquet murdred his brother Am
non. the verye same Absalom also
Davids sonne, defileth or deflowreth
his fathers wives, and that openly too,
laying all feare of God and shame a
side. Hee driveth his father out of his
kingdome, and hasteneth on to shorten
his daies. Al which calamities David
confesseth, that he doth worthily su
staine, for the adulterie * murther by
him committed. Lastly, many thou
sands of his people were slayne in the
battaile: David himselfe is harly and
with much a doe restored to his king
dome, and afterward beeyng restored,
hee repented his sinne all the dayes of
his life.
Now it is marvel, if adulterers (cou
dering these punishets) will goe on yet

ofspring. For they are against al right robbed of their due inheritance, wher of an equall position is given to him, to whom by lawe no parcell is due. Last ly beside all these, innumerable mis chiefers doe spring of adulterie. Since therefore that it is a Serpent with so many heads, both the lawes of God & me doe rightly punish adulterers with losse of life. But some jolly fellowes there are forsooth, that of adultery do make but a sport. They are perswaded that Da vids adultery doth make on their side, and that place of scripture, where wee read, that the Lord was savourable to the adulteresse, that was taken eve as the deede was in doing. Why doe not these merrye conceyted men consider howe severely the Lorde did punishe David for that offence? The bloudye house of David was immediatly after defiled with filthie incest. For Amnon doth perforce defloure his sister Tha mar. And streight way upon the necke of that again, his house is defamed by most cruell parricide, while Absolom in a banquet murdred his brother Am non. the verye same Absalom also Davids sonne, defileth or deflowreth his fathers wives, and that openly too, laying all feare of God and shame a side. Hee driveth his father out of his kingdome, and hasteneth on to shorten his daies. Al which calamities David confesseth, that he doth worthily su staine, for the adulterie * murther by him committed. Lastly, many thou sands of his people were slayne in the battaile: David himselfe is harly and with much a doe restored to his king dome, and afterward beeyng restored, hee repented his sinne all the dayes of his life. Now it is marvel, if adulterers (cou dering these punishets) will goe on yet
